title: How to Make an Origami Patty Bat

steps.headline: Choose the paper you want to use.
steps.description: Almost any paper will do, but the most common is printer paper and origami paper.

steps.headline: Fold the long side of the printer paper in half.
steps.description: Crease the paper neatly and unfold the paper again.

steps.headline: Take the bottom corner of the right half and fold it to the crease line.
steps.description: Pay attention not to cover the crease line but rather leave a very small gap.

steps.headline: Take the bottom corner of the left side and fold it to the crease line.
steps.description: Remember to leave a very small gap when folding so as not to cover the crease line.

steps.headline: Rotate the paper so the point of the triangle is facing away from you.
Take the bottom rectangular edge and bend it over to the two flaps that form the triangle portion of the paper and make a small pinch mark in the center.
steps.description: Do not make a full crease but rather a small fold.

steps.headline: Fold the new edge created in the last step o the pinch mark.
Take the corner of the bottom right side and fold it inward toward the triangle flap.
steps.description: Remember to leave a small gap when folding so as not to cover the crease line.

steps.headline: Take the corner of the bottom left side and fold it inward toward the triangle flap.
Take the newly created bottom section and fold it up.
steps.description: Make a thorough and complete crease line.

steps.headline: Fold the triangular portion to the back and pinch it so that it aligns with the edge below it.
steps.description: Once aligned make a thorough and complete crease line.

steps.headline: Flip the paper to the other side.
Fold the lower edge of the trapezoid piece to the upper edge making a very small pinch mark in the center.
steps.description: The easiest way to make this pinch mark is to use one finger and press firmly in the center of the fold.

steps.headline: Take the right slanted edge and bring it to the center line.
Take the left slanted edge and bring it to the center line.
Take the inner point of the right side and fold it to the outer point on the same side.
steps.description: Crease well. This step will be easier if you rotate the paper and fold away from yourself.

steps.headline: Make a crease that aligns with the edge you just created.
Make another crease that aligns with the edge just created.
One final time, make a crease that aligns with the edge just created.
Repeat the previous four steps with the left side of the paper.
steps.description: Make sure all creases are complete and neat as possible.

steps.headline: Fold the triangle piece at the top of the paper downward, leaving a good-sized gap.
steps.description: Crease well. This will be the head of the bat.

steps.headline: Open the folds on the left and right sides.
steps.description: These will be the wings of the bat.

steps.headline: Flip the paper over.
To create the action portion of the patty bat, place your thumb on the head and your middle finger on the back of the bat so that your thumb and middle finger are parallel to each other.
Place your index finger on the underside of the bat.
Bend the wings upward with your left hand as you push your thumb and middle finger together and your index finger up.
steps.description: This creates a crease in the middle of the bat that allows you to continue the flap action of the patty bat.

text: Choose the paper you want to use. Almost any paper will do, but the most common is printer paper and origami paper. Fold the long side of the printer paper in half. Crease the paper neatly and unfold the paper again. Take the bottom corner of the right half and fold it to the crease line. Pay attention not to cover the crease line but rather leave a very small gap. Take the bottom corner of the left side and fold it to the crease line. Remember to leave a very small gap when folding so as not to cover the crease line. Rotate the paper so the point of the triangle is facing away from you.  Take the bottom rectangular edge and bend it over to the two flaps that form the triangle portion of the paper and make a small pinch mark in the center. Do not make a full crease but rather a small fold. Fold the new edge created in the last step o the pinch mark. Crease it completely. Take the corner of the bottom right side and fold it inward toward the triangle flap. Remember to leave a small gap when folding so as not to cover the crease line. Take the corner of the bottom left side and fold it inward toward the triangle flap.  Take the newly created bottom section and fold it up. Make a thorough and complete crease line. Fold the triangular portion to the back and pinch it so that it aligns with the edge below it. Once aligned make a thorough and complete crease line. Flip the paper to the other side.  Fold the lower edge of the trapezoid piece to the upper edge making a very small pinch mark in the center. The easiest way to make this pinch mark is to use one finger and press firmly in the center of the fold. Take the right slanted edge and bring it to the center line.  Take the left slanted edge and bring it to the center line.  Take the inner point of the right side and fold it to the outer point on the same side. Crease well. This step will be easier if you rotate the paper and fold away from yourself. Make a crease that aligns with the edge you just created.  Make another crease that aligns with the edge just created.  One final time, make a crease that aligns with the edge just created.  Repeat the previous four steps with the left side of the paper. Make sure all creases are complete and neat as possible. Fold the triangle piece at the top of the paper downward, leaving a good-sized gap. Crease well. This will be the head of the bat. Open the folds on the left and right sides. These will be the wings of the bat. Flip the paper over.  To create the action portion of the patty bat, place your thumb on the head and your middle finger on the back of the bat so that your thumb and middle finger are parallel to each other.  Place your index finger on the underside of the bat.  Bend the wings upward with your left hand as you push your thumb and middle finger together and your index finger up. This creates a crease in the middle of the bat that allows you to continue the flap action of the patty bat.
